Even though she is on the pill form... Metformin?

I think her being so young, being young and pregnant is usually considered higher risk and being diabetic are two things that make her a very good candidate for a specialist.  I would ask her endocrinologist for a few names of good OB-GYN's that specialize in high risk pregnancies.I am a Type 1 diabetic, and have had two healthy children.  It is harder when you are diabetic because you must carefully monitor your blood glucose levels too keep them in a good range for the baby and the mother.  If blood sugars are not under control the baby can have a higher birthweight and other complications as well.  Diabetics often have trouble with blood pressure during pregnancies as well.  I am not telling you this to scare you, but I think the more informed you are the better.  I also think making sure you have experienced and knowledgeable physicians will make your daughter's pregnancy a healthy one.
So I will have to learn to give her a shot, I don't know if I can do this, we are fairly new to all of this and it really scary!

Hi soonerfan69,Don't be afraid to help with giving the shots. My girlfriend has to takes shots regularly, and she wanted me to give her one so I knew how to do it. At first i was petrified, but I overcame my fear and learned it. Last weekend, we were on vacation, and she passed out from her sugar being so hi. Luckily since i was aware of how to give the shots, I was able to stabilize her and get her to help quickly. So learning to do the shots will be a great help.

I have to comment about this---I know that honeytheone is trying to be helpful but is not a doctor and does not know for certain if your daughter will have to be on insulin during her pregnancy.  I think you need to consult her endocrinologist and ob-gyn about that.  Don't start worrying until you know for certain.  And of course you will be able to help your daughter through whatever is necessary, that is what we mothers do.

I agree that if your daughter is producing insulin (as a type 2) of her own, she may continue to do fine on her Metformin, but the dosage may change. She absolutely should see a diabetes specialist during her pregnancy, for as CB said, there are risks to both mother and baby that can be avoided with good medical care. I, too, am mother to 2 healthy children, and wish her a safe pregnancy. The key is good medical care from someone who knows the special issues that both baby and mom will deal with because of her diabetes.
